turn.1: What is the difference between Barratt-Priddy theorem and other homotopy theorems?
turn.2: Barratt–Priddy theorem In homotopy theory, a branch of mathematics, the Barratt–Priddy theorem (also referred to as Barratt–Priddy– Quillen theorem) expresses a connection between the homology of the symmetric groups and mapping spaces of spheres.
turn.3: What is the result of the theorem?
turn.4: It is also often stated as a relation between the sphere spectrum and the classifying spaces of the symmetric groups via Quillen's plus construction.
turn.5: What is the definition of the mapping space?
turn.6: The mapping space is the topological space of all continuous maps from the -dimensional sphere to itself, under the topology of uniform convergence (a special case of the compact-open topology).
turn.7: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.8: These maps are required to fix a basepoint , satisfying , and to have degree 0; this guarantees that the mapping space is connected.
turn.10: The Barratt–Priddy theorem expresses a relation between the homology of these mapping spaces and the homology of the symmetric groups .
